content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’m here because my wife insisted I talk to someone. Things at home have been so hard lately with our son acting out, and it’s really putting a strain on everything—my marriage, my focus at work, even just feeling okay day-to-day. Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start.

It sounds like there’s been a lot on your plate lately, and it’s been weighing on different parts of your life—your marriage, work, and even how you’re feeling personally. It can be hard to navigate all of that at once. What’s been the most challenging part of this for you?

I think the hardest part has been feeling like I don’t know how to help my son. It’s frustrating and exhausting, and my wife and I can’t seem to agree on what to do. It’s creating this distance between us, and I just feel stuck.

It must be so difficult to feel unsure about how to help your son while also navigating the tension it’s creating with your wife. It sounds like you care deeply about your family and want to be there for them, but feeling stuck is making it all the more overwhelming. What do you think has been keeping you from deciding on a way forward together?

I think part of it is that my wife and I see things differently. She has ideas about what might work, and I don’t always agree, or sometimes I just feel too exhausted to even try new things. We’re not really on the same page, and that makes it hard to act as a team.

It seems like the differences in how you and your wife approach things, combined with the exhaustion you’re feeling, have made it hard to find common ground and work together. That sounds really challenging. What do you think would help you both feel more like a team again?

Honestly, I’m not sure. We’ve tried talking about it, but it always seems to turn into frustration or arguments. Maybe if we could communicate better without it escalating, we’d feel more like we’re in it together. But I don’t even know where to start with that either.

It sounds like you really value being able to communicate openly with your wife and work together as a team, but the frustration and arguments make that feel tough right now. Wanting to improve that connection shows how much this matters to you. What do you think makes it hard to have those conversations stay calm and productive?

Maybe it's because we’re both so stressed and emotional about everything going on with our son. It feels like there’s so much pressure to fix everything, and when we don’t agree, it’s like the weight of it all just spills out. It’s hard to keep calm when everything feels so overwhelming.

That weight and pressure you’re feeling sound exhausting, especially when it intensifies during those tough conversations. It sounds like both you and your wife really care and are feeling the stress of wanting to do what’s best for your son. How do you usually cope with the stress when it builds up like that?
Honestly, I haven’t been coping well. I mostly just shut down and withdraw because I don’t know what else to do. It feels like there’s no room to even breathe, let alone handle everything.

Withdrawing might feel like the only way to protect yourself when it all feels overwhelming, especially when you’re not sure where to start. It’s clear that this has been a very heavy burden for you. What do you think you need right now to feel like you could just catch your breath?

I guess I just need some space to think clearly and not feel so overwhelmed all the time. Maybe a way to take things one step at a time instead of feeling like everything is crashing down at once. I don’t know how to do that, though.

It makes sense that you’re craving some space to think clearly and break things down—managing it all at once sounds like a lot. Taking it one step at a time could help things feel less overwhelming. What’s one small step that you think might help you create a bit of that space for yourself?

Maybe I could try to take a little time for myself each day, even if it’s just a walk or sitting quietly. It’s hard to imagine finding the time, but maybe starting small could help me feel less drained. I could give that a shot.

That sounds like a thoughtful and manageable idea—giving yourself even a small moment just for you might help ease some of that constant stress. It’s encouraging that you’re open to trying. How do you feel about exploring ways to make that small step fit into your day?

I think I could try to carve out 10 or 15 minutes during lunch or after work. I’d have to make it a priority, which feels hard when there’s so much going on, but I know I can’t keep running on empty. It’s worth trying, at least.

That’s a really meaningful step you’re thinking about—making space for just 10 or 15 minutes could be a way to recharge and take care of yourself, even with everything else happening. It seems like you’re recognizing the importance of filling your own tank to manage everything more effectively. Would you like to talk about what might help you stick with this plan or anything else on your mind?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
